body:
### Describe your change:
Added the NEAT Algorithm from scratch in python which is an evolutionary algorithm based on the paper by Kenneth O. Stanley. It uses only basic python libraries and pygame only for visualization. This makes it easy to implement in other programs. One example of its use can be found on our [FlappyNEAT](https://github.com/kshitijaucharmal/FlappyNEAT) repo where we demonstrate a flappy bird game playing on its own through NEAT.

### Proposed Changes:

* Type hints aren't removed.
* No test cases are removed. 
* Used keyword arguments for the "factors" parameter as using Union is not supported below Python version 3.10.
* Replaced the match case with if-elif-else statements. 
* Code is passing all `doctest` test cases.
* Code is passing all the formatting checks (Done using  `pre-commit` tool).

### Describe your change:
I am adding a new problem known as the "Minimum Segment Intersection Problem" to the project. This problem is used to find the minimum number of points needed to cover all the given segments efficiently. I've implemented a Python solution utilizing a greedy algorithmic approach

### Describe your change:

Related Issue #8594

- ### Refactored is_pandigital_both()
    - Rename `check()` -> `is_pandigital_both()`
    - **Removed duplicate code**, now it uses `is_pandigital_end` to check both sides of the given number

- ### Refactored is_pandigital_end()
    - Rename `check1()` -> `is_pandigital_end()`
    - Rename variable `check_last` -> `digit_count`
    - Change **length** of `digit_count` from `11 -> 10`
    - Replace `second for loop` -> `all()` because of *ruff error SIM110*
    - Redundant flag variable `f` is removed

- ### Refactored solution()
    - Added parameters `a: int, b: int, ck: int, max_k: int`
    - Variables renamed:
        - `a, b, c` -> `fk_2, fk_1, fk` because `fk` is k'th fibonacci number, `fk_2 = f(k-2)` etc.
        - `a1, b1, c1` -> `mk_2, mk_1, mk` because `mk_2 = f(k-2) % billion` etc.
        - `m` -> `billion`
        - `tocheck` ->`end_pandigital`
        - `x` -> `k`
    - For loop's range changed from `range(1_000_000)` -> `range(3, 1_000_000)` and `tocheck[x + 3]` -> `end_pandigital[k]`

- ### Updated docstrings
    - Docstrings are updated for all three functions

Added KMP algorithm. The Knuth-Morris-Pratt (KMP) algorithm is a string searching and pattern matching algorithm implemented in this Python code. It efficiently finds occurrences of a pattern (given by pat) within a text (given by txt) while avoiding unnecessary character comparisons by utilizing the Longest Prefix Suffix (LPS) array.

### Describe your change:

Fixed-priority preemptive scheduling is a [scheduling system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_multitasking) commonly used in [real-time systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_system). With fixed priority preemptive scheduling, the scheduler ensures that at any given time, the [processor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit) executes the highest priority [task](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Task_(computing)) of all those tasks that are currently ready to execute.

### Describe your change:

Title: Implement Priority Round Robin Scheduler in Python

Description:
Implement a Priority Round Robin scheduler in Python. This code uses a class-based approach to model jobs, where each job has a name, priority, burst time, and a sequentially assigned job number. The priority round robin scheduling algorithm is applied to execute the jobs.

Changes Made:
- Added a `Job` class with attributes for name, priority, burst time, and a sequentially assigned job number.
- Implemented a `priority_rr_scheduling` function to perform priority round robin scheduling.
- The code takes user input for the total number of jobs, job names, priorities, burst times, and the time quantum.
- Automatically assigns job numbers to each job in sequential order.
- Prints the order in which jobs are completed and the time at which each job completes its execution.

File Name: priority_rr_scheduler.py

```

```

Since we're not testing files in the `project_euler/` or `scripts/` directories, we should exclude them from our builds' coverage reports as well. `project_euler/` files in particular significantly clutter the reports.

### Describe your change:

Disable unused dependencies in `requirements.txt` to try to reduce build times:
- Keras is a TensorFlow frontend, so I've also marked it as `python_version < '3.12'`. There's no reason to install Keras in every build when TensorFlow can't be used.
- projectq, scikit-fuzzy, and yulewalker are only used by broken (and thus disabled) files, so I've commented them out. If/when those broken files are fixed, we can uncomment them.

### Charging of Inductor

With the help of this algorithm we can easily find the current at any nth second in the
inductor while the inductor being charged. It is all because of the RL-timeconstant.
when an inductor is connected with a resistor in series it gives a exponential function. It is very
helpful when we making or designing new circuits, thus we have decide which inductor and
resistor we should choose.

### Charging of Inductor

With the help of this algorithm we can easily find the current at any nth second in the 
inductor while the inductor being charged. It is all because of the RL-timeconstant.
when an inductor is connected with a resistor in series it gives a exponential function. It is very 
helpful when we making or designing new circuits, thus we have decide which inductor and 
resistor we should choose.

### Describe your change:

Contributes to #9718 by fixing the numpy deprecation warning in `neural_networks/2_hidden_layers_neural_network.py`:
```
neural_network/2_hidden_layers_neural_network.py::neural_network.2_hidden_layers_neural_network.TwoHiddenLayerNeuralNetwork.predict
neural_network/2_hidden_layers_neural_network.py::neural_network.2_hidden_layers_neural_network.example
  /home/runner/work/Python/Python/neural_network/2_hidden_layers_neural_network.py:224: DeprecationWarning: Conversion of an array with ndim > 0 to a scalar is deprecated, and will error in future. Ensure you extract a single element from your array before performing this operation. (Deprecated NumPy 1.25.)
    return int(self.layer_between_second_hidden_layer_and_output > 0.6)
```

Function return types and parameter types are included in the comments for better code documentation.
Multiline comments explain the purpose and functionality of each function.
The code focuses exclusively on stochastic gradient descent and does not include the original gradient descent code.

The Euler's Phi function doctest is worse than the other functions' doctests in the same file, only covering one case and lacking exception handling for negative numbers, unlike the other functions. Fixes #9598

The MLP class implements a simple feedforward neural network for classification. It has an input layer, a hidden layer with a tanh activation, and an output layer.

The init() method initializes the weight matrices and bias vectors randomly.

The forward() method performs the feedforward pass, calculating the outputs from the input data using the weights/biases.

The fit() method trains the network using backpropagation and gradient descent. It:

Makes predictions
Calculates the loss
Computes gradients of the loss with respect to the weights/biases
Updates the weights/biases to reduce the loss
This allows the MLP to learn non-linear functions approximators and fit to training data for tasks like classification. The network is trained iteratively using backprop and gradient descent to minimize the loss.

In summary, the MLP class implements a basic neural network that can be trained on data to perform machine learning tasks by learning to make data-driven predictions and decisions.

The provided Python script offers a solution to the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP), a renowned combinatorial optimization challenge. The approach employed in this code is a straightforward brute-force method that exhaustively explores all possible permutations of a given set of points to identify the optimal path. To begin, the script imports the permutations function from the itertools library, which plays a pivotal role in generating every conceivable permutation of the input points. A calculate_total_distance function computes the overall distance for a given order of points by employing the Euclidean distance formula. The heart of the code, the tsp_bruteforce function, iterates through these permutations, calculating their distances and maintaining records of the best path and its total distance. The main function functions as the program's entry point, soliciting user input to determine the number of points and their coordinates. Upon receiving user input, the script engages the TSP solver to identify the most efficient path and compute its total distance. If executed directly, rather than being imported as a module, the script initiates the TSP solving process.

Instead of explicitly appending values to a list in the inorder traversal, it uses a generator function, which is more memory-efficient and Pythonic. Simplified the insertion logic by using if val < self.val: and if val > self.val: conditions. Removed the unnecessary check for if self.val: in the insert method, as it's not needed. Replaced if len(arr) == 0: with if not arr: for a more Pythonic way of checking if the list is empty. These changes make the code cleaner and more efficient while maintaining the same functionality.

added ant_colony_optimization

### Describe your change: I have created a function for Ant-colony-Optimization algorithm used for path finding



* [x] #Algorithm :
* 1 ] Initialization: Initialize the problem with a random configuration of pheromone levels on the edges and place ants on random nodes in the graph.

2 ] Ant Movement: Each ant starts moving through the graph. At each step, an ant chooses the next node to visit based on a combination of pheromone levels and the distance to the node.
Solution Construction: Ants construct solutions by iteratively moving from one node to another. They continue until all nodes are visited.
3 ] Pheromone Update: After all ants have completed their tours, pheromone levels are updated. Edges that are part of better solutions receive more pheromone. 
4 ] Iteration: Steps 2-4 are repeated for a fixed number of iterations or until a stopping condition is met.
5 ] Solution Improvement: The best solution found by the ants is considered the result of the optimization process.

### Describe your change:

The Bernoulli principle is a fundamental concept in fluid dynamics that describes the relationship between the pressure and velocity of a fluid in a streamlined flow. You can use Python to create a simple script to visualize the Bernoulli principle. In this example, I have use the Matplotlib library to create a plot that demonstrates the principle.

Algorithm:-

1. import `numpy` as np and import `matplotlib.pyplot as plt`: These lines import the NumPy library as "np" and the Matplotlib library as "plt." NumPy is used for numerical calculations, and Matplotlib is used for creating plots and visualizations.

2. `v = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)`: This line creates an array v of 100 equally spaced values between 0 and 10. This array represents a range of velocities.

3. `pressure_constant = 1.0`: This line sets a constant value for the Bernoulli equation. In this example, it's set to 1.0 for simplicity, but in real-world applications, this constant would be specific to the fluid and conditions being analyzed.

4. `pressure = pressure_constant - 0.5 * v**2`: This line calculates the pressure using the Bernoulli equation. It relates the pressure and velocity of a fluid in a streamlined flow. The result is stored in the pressure array.

5. `plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))`: This line creates a new figure for the plot with a specified size (8 units wide and 6 units high).

6. `plt.plot(v, pressure)`: This line plots the data. It uses the array v as the x-axis (velocity) and the array pressure as the y-axis (pressure).

7. `plt.title("Bernoulli Principle Visualization")`: This line sets the title of the plot.

8. `plt.xlabel("Velocity") and plt.ylabel("Pressure")`: These lines set labels for the x-axis and y-axis, respectively.

9. `plt.grid(True)`: This line adds a grid to the plot for better readability.

10. `plt.show()`: Finally, this line displays the plot. When you run the script, a graphical window should appear showing a plot of pressure vs. velocity, illustrating the Bernoulli principle.

Features:-

Collects and calculates credit scores based on user input for the following factors:
Age
Credit history (in months)
Annual income
Total debt
Outstanding credit amount
Number of recent delinquencies (last 12 months)
Credit utilization ratio
Utilizes weighted factors and mathematical functions to calculate a base credit score.
Adjusts the base score to ensure it falls within the typical credit score range of 300 to 850.

Usage:-

Clone this repository to your local machine or download the script.
Run the Python script using your preferred Python interpreter.
Follow the prompts to input your financial and personal information.
The program will calculate and display your estimated credit score.

### Describe your change:
This algorithm is a brute-force search over (nearly) all 2^n possible partitions and was created for educational purposes. The asymptotic runtime of this code is: O(n * 2^n) this is a case of the partition problem. It accepts a multiset ( list ) of integers, distributes them, and returns a tuple, containing two lists, with minimal difference between their sums.

### Describe your change:

Contributes to #9718

before:
```
("sum", np.sum),
*******************
("mean_with_na", np.mean),
```
after:
```
("sum", "sum"),
******************
("mean_with_na", "mean"),
```

the change removes the warning:

```
/home/runner/work/Python/Python/machine_learning/k_means_clust.py:236: FutureWarning: The provided callable <function sum at 0x7f20c02034c0> is currently using SeriesGroupBy.sum. In a future version of pandas, the provided callable will be used directly. To keep current behavior pass the string "sum" instead.
     .agg(
```

And

```
/home/runner/work/Python/Python/machine_learning/k_means_clust.py:236: FutureWarning: The provided callable <function mean at 0x7f3d7db1c5e0> is currently using SeriesGroupBy.mean. In a future version of pandas, the provided callable will be used directly. To keep current behavior pass the string "mean" instead.
     .agg(
```
